IP2026031_syn_2:
INDICATION: [REDACTED], a 62-year-old female with severe, refractory COPD and RUL-predominant emphysematous changes, presented for intervention.
PROCEDURE: The patient was placed under general anesthesia using a laryngeal mask airway. The right bronchial tree was systematically mapped. Collateral ventilation was assessed via the Chartis system in the RUL, demonstrating a 'low flow/no plateau' phenotype consistent with fissure integrity. Subsequently, three Zephyr endobronchial valves were deployed in the apical, posterior, and anterior segments.
OUTCOME: Post-deployment fluoroscopy confirmed appropriate valve positioning. Clinical examination revealed decreased ventilation to the target lobe. A transient episode of hypoxemia occurred intraoperatively, which responded promptly to recruitment maneuvers and increased fraction of inspired oxygen.

IP2026031:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction with endobronchial valve placement, right upper lobe.
Patient: [REDACTED], 63-year-old female with severe COPD and upper-lobeâ€“predominant emphysema refractory to optimal medical management.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with laryngeal mask airway (size 4 LMA).
Indication: Symptomatic severe emphysema with marked RUL hyperinflation and exercise limitation despite guideline-directed COPD therapy.
Pre-procedure imaging and physiology: CT chest demonstrating severe heterogeneous emphysema with RUL-predominant disease and intact minor fissure. Perfusion scan with relative preservation of perfusion to contralateral lung. Baseline FEV1 29% predicted, DLCO 35% predicted.
Collateral ventilation assessment: Chartis assessment performed in the RUL bronchus demonstrated rapid flow decline to zero with stable plateau, consistent with absence of collateral ventilation.
Procedure details: A therapeutic flexible bronchoscope was advanced via the LMA. The right bronchial tree was inspected and the RUL bronchus cannulated. Chartis assessment confirmed suitability for BLVR. Three Zephyr endobronchial valves were then deployed in the apical, posterior, and anterior segmental bronchi. Valve positions were verified bronchoscopically and fluoroscopically. After several minutes of observation, there was decreased ventilation to the RUL and modest mediastinal shift toward the treated side, without hemodynamic compromise.
Complications: No significant bleeding. Transient mild hypoxemia during valve deployment, resolved with increased FiO2 and recruitment maneuvers. No immediate pneumothorax on post-procedure CXR.
Disposition: Recovered in PACU and admitted to monitored bed for routine post-BLVR observation.
Plan: Serial chest radiographs x 3 days, bronchodilators and incentive spirometry, outpatient PFTs at 3 months, and follow-up in BLVR clinic.
